verses.text: On the third day, there was a wedding in Cana of Galilee, and the mother of Jesus was there.
verses.comment: The setting is a real, historical event. The presence of Jesus's mother is specifically noted, showing her unique role in His life and ministry (see also John 19:25).

verses.text: Jesus also was invited to the wedding, with His disciples.
verses.comment: Jesus attends the wedding with His disciples, affirming the goodness of marriage and social celebration. This also initiates His public ministry with His followers present.

verses.text: When the wine ran out, the mother of Jesus said to Him, 'They have no wine.'
verses.comment: Mary intercedes on behalf of those in need, demonstrating her compassionate concern and her role as an intercessor. She trusts Jesus' authority, implicitly acknowledging His capacity to act.

verses.text: And Jesus said to her, 'Woman, what does this have to do with Me? My hour has not yet come.'
verses.comment: Jesus addresses Mary as 'Woman,' which, though formal, recalls the Genesis promise of the 'woman' (Gen. 3:15). 'My hour' refers to the time of His Passion (John 12:23), showing a distinction between divine timing and human concerns. Yet, He does not reject her request.

verses.text: His mother said to the servants, 'Do whatever He tells you.'
verses.comment: Mary’s instruction to obey Jesus emphasizes her intimate faith and authority. Her words echo the call to discipleship: to listen and act according to Jesus’ commands. This reflects a model of obedient faith.

verses.text: Now there were six stone water jars there for the Jewish rites of purification, each holding twenty or thirty gallons.
verses.comment: These large stone jars were used for ritual purification (see Mark 7:3-4; Exod. 30:18). Jesus will transform water used for external cleansing into wine, symbolizing a new and greater spiritual reality.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'Fill the jars with water.' And they filled them to the brim.
verses.comment: The servants' complete obedience displays trust. The filling ‘to the brim’ highlights both abundance and the superabundant grace brought by Jesus.

verses.text: Then He said to them, 'Now draw some and take it to the master of the feast.' So they took it.
verses.comment: The transformation takes place in obedience and in secret at first, reminiscent of other miraculous feeding narratives and pointing to the coming Eucharistic reality.

verses.text: When the master of the feast tasted the water that had become wine, he did not know where it came from, though the servants who had drawn the water knew. The master of the feast called the bridegroom
verses.comment: The master’s ignorance and the servants’ knowledge stress the mysterious, divine action. Jesus’ identity is gradually revealed through signs. The bridegroom here foreshadows Christ as the ultimate bridegroom (see Eph. 5:25-32).

verses.text: and said to him, 'Everyone serves the good wine first, and when people have drunk freely, then the poorer wine. But you have kept the good wine until now.'
verses.comment: The best wine coming last signifies the fulfillment of God’s promises in Christ—He brings something far superior to what came before (see Heb. 1:1-2).

verses.text: This, the first of His signs, Jesus did at Cana of Galilee, and manifested His glory. And His disciples believed in Him.
verses.comment: This is the first ‘sign’ revealing Jesus’ divine glory (see John 1:14), leading to increased faith. The sign points to Jesus’ identity and divinity—such faith involves seeing with spiritual eyes.

verses.text: After this He went down to Capernaum, with His mother, His brothers, and His disciples, and they stayed there for a few days.
verses.comment: The mention of Jesus’ family and disciples together highlights the unity of His followers. 'Brothers' can also mean close relatives (see Mark 3:31-35). This sets the context for His coming public acts.

verses.text: The Passover of the Jews was at hand, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Passover recalls God’s deliverance. Jesus' presence in Jerusalem at Passover points to His fulfillment of Old Testament festivals and His identity as the true Lamb (cf. Exod. 12:1-14; John 1:29).

verses.text: In the temple He found those who were selling oxen and sheep and pigeons, and the money changers sitting there.
verses.comment: Jesus confronts those turning a place of worship into a place of commerce. This act fulfills prophetic warnings about the sanctity of God’s house (see Zech. 14:21).

verses.text: And making a whip out of cords, He drove them all out of the temple, with the sheep and oxen. And He poured out the coins of the money changers and overturned their tables.
verses.comment: Christ’s righteous anger shows zeal for pure worship. His forceful cleansing fulfills the expectation of Messianic zeal for God’s house (see Ps. 69:9).

verses.text: Then He told those who sold pigeons, 'Take these things away; do not make My Father's house a house of trade.'
verses.comment: Calling the Temple 'My Father’s house' is a bold claim to divine sonship (see also John 5:18), affirming His unique relationship to the Father and authority over worship. The allusion to Ps. 69:9 gives both literal and spiritual meaning.

verses.text: His disciples remembered that it is written, 'Zeal for your house will consume me.'
verses.comment: This is a direct fulfillment of Psalm 69:9. The disciples interpret Jesus’ actions as fulfilling Messianic prophecy and pointing to His coming passion.

verses.text: So the Jews said to Him, 'What sign do You show us for doing these things?'
verses.comment: The authorities challenge Jesus’ right to act in the temple. The demand for a sign is a theme throughout the Gospels, pointing to apprehension about Jesus' divine authority.

verses.text: Jesus answered them, 'Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up.'
verses.comment: Jesus prophesies His Resurrection. 'This temple' refers to His body (see John 2:21), foreshadowing the new Temple: His resurrected body, the dwelling place of God among men.

verses.text: Then the Jews said, 'It has taken forty-six years to build this temple, and will you raise it up in three days?'
verses.comment: The Jews interpret 'temple' only in the literal sense, missing the spiritual meaning. Their misunderstanding is common in John’s Gospel, highlighting the need for deeper insight.

verses.text: But He was speaking about the temple of His body.
verses.comment: John explains the spiritual meaning: Jesus is the new and true Temple where God dwells fully among us (see John 1:14; 1 Cor. 3:16).

verses.text: When therefore He was raised from the dead, His disciples remembered that He had said this, and they believed the Scripture and the word that Jesus had spoken.
verses.comment: The disciples’ faith grows as they connect Jesus’ words to Scripture, showing the importance of the unified tradition of apostolic witness and fulfillment of prophecy (see Ps. 16:10).

verses.text: Now when He was in Jerusalem at the Passover Feast, many believed in His name when they saw the signs He was doing.
verses.comment: Jesus’ miracles elicit faith, but John’s Gospel often distinguishes between superficial and deeper faith based on real spiritual commitment (see John 20:31).

verses.text: But Jesus on His part was not entrusting Himself to them, because He knew all people
verses.comment: Jesus possesses divine knowledge of the heart (see 1 Sam. 16:7), distinguishing true faith from mere enthusiasm for His miracles.

verses.text: and because He had no need for anyone to testify about man, for He Himself knew what was in man.
verses.comment: Jesus has divine insight into human nature (Ps. 139:1-4). His knowledge is all-encompassing, affirming His divinity. This anticipates the spiritual discernment required of His followers.
